## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**AI Assistant:**
Hey! I'm here to help answer any questions you have about Verus. What's on your mind today?

**User:**
I've been thinking about using an i-address as an ID name. Is that a good idea?

**AI Assistant:**
Actually, using an i-address as an ID name can cause issues. It can lead to confusion when referring to a currency or identity. To reduce user confusion, the naming system will expand the set of characters that are not allowed for currency registrations. It's better to avoid using an i-address as an ID name to prevent potential problems.

**User:**
That makes sense. I was also thinking about creating currencies from IDs in Verus. Are there any limitations to that?

**AI Assistant:**
Yes, there is a limitation. You cannot create a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. To avoid problems, it's recommended to avoid doing this. Instead, choose a different name for your ID or currency.

**User:**
I see. I've also seen a disclaimer when using the Verus software. What does it say, and what does it mean for users?

**AI Assistant:**
The disclaimer states that the software is experimental and unfinished, and users should use it at their own risk. The software is provided "AS IS", without warranty of any kind, and the authors or copyright holders are not liable for any claims, damages, or other liability arising from the use of the software. This implies that users should be cautious when using the software and understand that it may have bugs or issues that are not yet resolved.

**User:**
Okay, got it. Finally, I've been trying to create a PBaaS chain in the Verus Desktop GUI, but I'm running into an issue. Can you help me with that?

**AI Assistant:**
In the Verus Desktop GUI, you cannot create a PBaaS chain with the same name as a currency that is already supported, such as BTC or ETH. This limitation is considered errata for the testnet release and will be resolved before the mainnet release. So, try choosing a different name for your PBaaS chain, and it should work.
Why might using an i-address as an ID name cause issues, and how will this be addressed in the future?

Using an i-address as an ID name can cause issues because it can lead to confusion when referring to a currency or identity. To reduce user confusion, the naming system will expand the set of characters that are not allowed for currency registrations.

#### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of: 1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.### DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software.
